children.title: Aaron
children.comment: The elder brother of Moses and Miriam. He served as a spokesman for his brother in the confrontation with Pharoah, which eventually led to the exodus from Egypt. He was later consecrated as high priest.

children.title: Aaron, spokesman for Moses
children.comment: He was called by God to speak for his brother Moses in the confrontation with Pharaoh and to lead the Israelites out of Egypt. Negligence of the LORD's express command cost him the privilege of entering the promised land.

children.title: Aaron was spokesman for Moses in Egypt
The brothers meet and confront Pharaoh
The command to lead the Israelites out of Egypt
The LORD's instructions for the Passover
The Israelites grumble against Moses and Aaron
Aaron commemorates the LORD's provision of manna
The meeting of Aaron and Jethro
Aaron makes the people a golden calf
The LORD prevents Aaron and Moses from entering the promised land
Aaron, as model priest
children.comment: Aaron was made high priest and charged with the responsibility of making offerings for the sins of the people and ensuring that the LORD was worshipped in the proper manner. His priesthood was to pass to his descendants, thus ensuring its continuity.

children.title: The significance of the priestly garments
Skilled craftsmen were employed in the making of the priestly garments
Fellow Levites were to help Aaron in ministry
In cities allotted to his descendants
Respect for the holiness of the LORD and his sanctuary
Tending the lamps in the Tent of Meeting
Obeying the LORD's commands about sacrificial ritual and offerings
Taking responsibility for the offences against the sanctuary and the priesthood
The LORD's requirements are to stand for all time
The priesthood continues through Aaron's descendants
Aaron, spokesman for Moses
children.comment: He was called by God to speak for his brother Moses in the confrontation with Pharaoh and to lead the Israelites out of Egypt. Negligence of the LORD's express command cost him the privilege of entering the promised land.

Abraham
children.comment: The OT patriarch born in Ur and called by God to live in Canaan. God promised to make his descendants into a great nation, a promise fulfilled initially in Israel, and subsequently in the Christian church. His trust in God is seen as exemplary by NT writers.

children.title: Abraham, life of
children.comment: God called Abraham to live as a nomad in Canaan and promised the land to his descendants, naming him ``father of many'', although he had no heir until his old age.

children.title: The line of descent from Shem to Abraham
Abraham was called to live in Canaan
His migration from Ur to Canaan
His nomadic way of life in Canaan
God gives Abraham his new name

primaryrefs.comment: The giving of a new name signifies a new relationship to God. ``Abram'' has the sense of ``revered father'', whereas ``Abraham'' means ``father of many people''.

children.title: Abraham buys a burial site for Sarah

primaryrefs.comment: This is his only acquisition of land in Canaan.

children.title: Abraham's dealings with his nephew, Lot

secondaryrefs.comment: Abraham is accompanied to Canaan by Lot
Abraham and Lot separate
Abraham rescues Lot from five local kings.
with three angels

children.title: God makes a covenant with Abraham
God gives Abram the name Abraham, as a sign of the covenant
God gives Abraham the gift of circumcision as a sign of the covenant
Abraham's pretence that Sarah is his sister
Abraham makes arrangements for a wife for Isaac
Abraham marries Keturah and has children by her
The time span of Abraham's life

secondaryrefs.comment: Abraham leaves Haran at the age of 75.
Abraham renamed and circumcised at the age of 99
Isaac born when Abraham is 100
Sarah dies when Abraham is 137. Ge 17:17 indicates that Sarah was ten years younger than Abraham
Abraham dies at the age of 175.

children.title: Abraham, character of
children.comment: Despite some shortcomings as a husband and father, his obedience, faith, hospitality and effective intercession were exemplary. Such qualities led to his being called ``friend of God''.

seealsos.comment: Abraham's faith is seen in the length of time (25 years) that he waited for the realisation of the promise

children.title: He was a prophet and intercessor

seealsos.comment: As a prophet, God reveals his will to Abraham; as an intercessor, Abraham brings the revelation back to God and pleads for him to change his mind.

children.title: He was called the friend of God
Abraham's weaknesses as head of his household
He was held responsible by God for his family

primaryrefs.comment: As the following references show, Abraham did not discharge this responsibility well.

children.title: He exploited his wife in a cowardly way
He fathered Ishmael as a result of wavering faith
He allowed Sarah to mistreat Hagar
Abraham's strengths as a member of society
He was well-respected outside his household
He sought to resolve disputes amicably
His wealth was a source of prestige
He was honoured for his military prowess
He was concerned to maintain his independence from the Canaanites
Abraham, significance of
children.comment: Whereas Jews see Abraham as the father of their nation on account of God's covenant with him, Christians see Abraham as the father of all who believe in Jesus Christ.

children.title: The significance of Abraham for nations other than Israel
Abraham was the father of many nations

seealsos.comment: Muslim Arabs trace their ancestry through Ishmael to Abraham.

children.title: Abraham was to be a means of blessing to many nations
The significance of Abraham for the people of Israel
Israel traces its origins back to God's call of Abraham
God promises the land of Canaan to Abraham's descendants
God is subsequently known in Israel as the God of Abraham
Abraham is seen as the father of the Jewish nation
God deals with Israel on the basis of his covenant with Abraham
Circumcision was the sign of participation in God's covenant with Abraham
The significance of Abraham for Christians
Abraham was an ancestor of Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ attacks Jewish confidence in mere physical descent from Abraham
Jesus Christ makes a point of identifying outcasts as children of Abraham
God's promise to Abraham is not inherited by those who obey the law
God's promise to Abraham is fulfilled in Jesus Christ, who is Abraham's seed
Abraham is the father of those who are justified by faith
Abraham's obedience to God shows that faith must lead to good works
Fellowship with Abraham is a symbol of salvation

Adam
children.comment: The Hebrew word ``adam'' is used both for ``man'' in general and also as the personal name of the first man that God created. It sounds like the word ``adamah'', meaning ``ground''.

children.title: Adam, creation and life of
children.comment: Adam is portrayed as the height of God's creation, made in the image and likeness of God, and entrusted with the stewardship of creation.

children.title: God's curse upon Adam and the earth
The life of Adam after the fall
Adam, significance of
children.comment: Throughout the NT, Adam is seen as a real historical figure, from whom all humanity is descended and by whose sin all humanity is affected.

children.title: Adam as the original member of the human race

seealsos.comment: The genealogy of Jesus Christ is traced back to Adam.

children.title: Adam as one flesh with Eve
Adam as the head of Eve
The reality and results of Adam's sin
Sin spread to all the human race
Death was introduced into the world
Condemnation for the human race resulted
Adam, and Jesus Christ
children.comment: Paul presents Jesus Christ as both the last Adam, succeeding where the first Adam failed, and the second man, standing at the head of a new humanity.

children.title: The contrast between the first and second Adam

primaryrefs.comment: By his sin Adam brought universal misery on humanity. In this he is the foreshadower and prototype of Jesus Christ, who through his righteous act brings the universal hope of redemption.

children.title: The contrast in nature of the first Adam and the second Adam
Adam was a living being; Jesus Christ is a life-giving being
Adam was natural, Jesus Christ is spiritual
Adam was earthly, Jesus Christ is heavenly
The contrast in the consequences of the actions of the first Adam and the second Adam
Adam brought death, Jesus Christ brings life
Adam brought judgment, Jesus Christ brings justification

children.comment: Adam is portrayed as the height of God's creation, made in the image and likeness of God, and entrusted with the stewardship of creation.

children.title: God's curse upon Adam and the earth

David
children.comment: The youngest son of Jesse and great-grandson of Ruth and Boaz, who became Israel's greatest king. Born in the town of Bethlehem, he probably lived c. 1040-970 B.C.

children.title: David, rise of
children.comment: David rose from humble origins to become Israel's greatest king. His rise to power is seen by OT writers as evidence of God's guiding hand upon both David and Israel.

children.title: David was the great-grandson of Ruth and Boaz
David was anointed king by Samuel
David was a member of Saul's court
The relationship between David and Saul
David, reign of
children.comment: David reigned over Judah for seven and a half years and over all Israel for 33 years. He extended the kingdom to the boundaries promised by God to Joshua.

children.title: David reigned over Judah in Hebron
David reigned over Israel in Jerusalem
David extended the boundaries of the kingdom
David's mightiest warriors were called ``the Thirty''
The struggle against the northern supporters of Saul
The census of Israel and Judah
Solomon succeeds David despite the claims of Adonijah
David, character of
children.comment: David, although not perfect, is portrayed as a man and a king after God's own heart.

children.title: His respect for those in authority
His deep humanity is evident in his paternal grief
He was a strategist and courageous commander
He was a musician and poet

secondaryrefs.comment: He sang

children.title: His military activities prevented him from building the temple
His adultery with Bathsheba and murder of Uriah
David, significance of
children.comment: David was instrumental in the establishment of Jerusalem as the centre of Israel's worship. Through David's personal rule, God exercised his own kingship over his people. David thus foreshadowed the Messiah, who would spring from his royal line.

children.title: The establishment of Jerusalem as the centre of worship
The son of God and chosen king
A sign of God's final victory
David as a type of Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ as the Son of David
Jesus Christ's kingship is linked with David's kingship
David, rise of
children.comment: David rose from humble origins to become Israel's greatest king. His rise to power is seen by OT writers as evidence of God's guiding hand upon both David and Israel.

Deborah
children.comment: An outstanding leader in Israel when the nation faced a crisis of resurgent Canaanite power in the time of the judges. Her name means ``bee''.

secondaryrefs.comment: She was probably called upon to settle intertribal disputes, ``mother in Israel'' meaning one who promotes the unity of God's family.

cschildren.title: Deborah's response to the Canaanite threat

children.title: She was petitioned by the people
She accompanied the army into battle
She led the people in victory celebration

secondaryrefs.comment: In this respect she is like Moses and Miriam (Ex 15:1,20).

children.title: She was wise, decisive, courageous, inspiring and bold

secondaryrefs.comment: Her confidence was in God's word and promise and she did not shrink from rebuking God's people.
These verses are a poetic acknowledgment that God has fought on Israel's behalf.

cschildren.title: She was God's person for the hour

children.title: Elijah
children.comment: Living in Israel, his ministry as a prophet was to oppose the worship of Baal in Israel, and the sin, injustices and idolatry of Ahab, Jezebel and Ahaziah. He came, probably, from Tishbe in Gilead, but his parentage is not certain. His name means ``the LORD is God''.

cschildren.title: Elijah's special standing as a prophet

children.title: His prophecies and prayers were fulfilled and attested by miracles

secondaryrefs.comment: provision of flour and oil prophesied
The widow's son is restored to life.

children.title: The word of the LORD came to him
He confronts Ahab, king of Israel
He challenges the people of Israel
He challenges Baal and his prophets
The prophets of Baal are sentenced to death and executed
Elijah calls down fire on Ahaziah's messengers
He appoints successors to continue the fight against Baal worshippers

seealsos.comment: Elisha is called
Jehu is anointed by one of Elisha's assistants.

cschildren.title: He does not die, but is taken up to heaven

children.title: He was a man of action and physical endurance

cschildren.title: Elijah's return is awaited by Israel

children.title: Some Jews believed John the Baptist was Elijah returned

seealsos.comment: John the Baptist denies being Elijah.

cschildren.title: Elijah appears at the transfiguration of Jesus Christ

children.title: Eve
children.comment: The wife of Adam and the first woman created. Her significance lies in being the first to be deceived and become disobedient to God. She is only given her name (which resembles the word for ``living'') by Adam after the expulsion from Eden.

cschildren.title: Eve was created in the image of God
Eve was a companion for Adam in Eden

children.title: Jacob
children.comment: The grandson of Abraham, and one of the two twin sons of Isaac. As the firstborn son of Isaac, Esau was entitled to inherit all of Isaac's property. However, he sold this to his brother Jacob to satisfy his immediate physical hunger. Through subsequent deception, Jacob was able to gain Isaac's blessing, and inherit all that was rightly Esau's. Despite such major faults, Scripture regards Jacob as further confirmation of God's promises to Abraham, and a model of faith and obedience.

children.title: Jacob, life and character of
children.comment: The grandson of Abraham and son of Isaac, who was chosen by God, despite his personal faults and shortcomings, to be the recipient of the promises made to Abraham. His name means ``he grasps the heel'', an allusion to the circumstances of his birth (Ge 25:25-26).

children.title: Jacob obtains the rights of the firstborn son
Jacob inherits the promises made to Abraham
As the result of Esau's enmity

secondaryrefs.comment: The encounter with God at Bethel confirms that Jacob has received the promise made to Abraham, and that Jacob has accepted his role of bearer of that promise to future generations.

seealsos.comment: Jacob is deceived by Laban into marrying Leah before Rachel.

primaryrefs.comment: The change of his name from ``Jacob'' (meaning ``he grasps the heel'', figuratively, ``he deceives'') to ``Israel'' (meaning ``he struggles with God'') confirms Jacob as the recipient of the Abrahamic blessings.

children.title: His favouritism towards Joseph and Benjamin
Jacob, the patriarch
children.comment: God's covenant promises to Abraham were inherited by Jacob, through his father Isaac, and so it was through his line of descent that the promised Messiah was to come.

children.title: Jacob was one of the three patriarchs
Jacob chosen in preference to Esau
The promises given to Jacob and his descendants
He was the father of the nation
Jacob as a symbol for the nation
Jacob and Israel were linked together as equivalent terms for the nation
The nation is described as the house of Jacob
Jacob, life and character of
children.comment: The grandson of Abraham and son of Isaac, who was chosen by God, despite his personal faults and shortcomings, to be the recipient of the promises made to Abraham. His name means ``he grasps the heel'', an allusion to the circumstances of his birth (Ge 25:25-26).

children.title: Jacob obtains the rights of the firstborn son
Jacob inherits the promises made to Abraham
As the result of Esau's enmity

secondaryrefs.comment: The encounter with God at Bethel confirms that Jacob has received the promise made to Abraham, and that Jacob has accepted his role of bearer of that promise to future generations.

seealsos.comment: Jacob is deceived by Laban into marrying Leah before Rachel.

primaryrefs.comment: The change of his name from ``Jacob'' (meaning ``he grasps the heel'', figuratively, ``he deceives'') to ``Israel'' (meaning ``he struggles with God'') confirms Jacob as the recipient of the Abrahamic blessings.

children.title: His favouritism towards Joseph and Benjamin
Jacob, the patriarch
children.comment: God's covenant promises to Abraham were inherited by Jacob, through his father Isaac, and so it was through his line of descent that the promised Messiah was to come.

children.title: Jacob was one of the three patriarchs
Jacob chosen in preference to Esau
The promises given to Jacob and his descendants
He was the father of the nation
Jacob as a symbol for the nation
Jacob and Israel were linked together as equivalent terms for the nation
The nation is described as the house of Jacob
John the Baptist
children.comment: The forerunner of Jesus Christ, born to elderly parents of the Aaronic line. His public ministry began in the Judean wilderness with a call to repentance and baptism. His ministry is seen as a fulfilment of OT prophecy, in preparation for the ministry of Jesus Christ. He was executed by Herod.

children.title: He was related to Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Just as roads were improved in the ancient world in preparation for the visit of a king, so John calls for people to prepare spiritually and morally for the imminent coming of the Messiah.

children.title: The contrast of his own baptism with that which the Messiah would bring
He recognises that his own ministry must decrease, while that of Jesus Christ will increase

seealsos.comment: John's reluctance to baptise Jesus Christ lay in his recognition of who Jesus was and the apparent inappropriateness of such a baptism

children.title: His disciples become envious of Jesus Christ
He sends his disciples to question Jesus Christ

secondaryrefs.comment: Locked up in prison, John needed reassurance that his expectations about Jesus Christ had been well-founded.

children.title: John's disciples and the first Christians
His confrontation with Herod leads to his imprisonment

cschildren.title: Some thought Jesus Christ to be John risen from the dead

children.title: Jesus Christ sees him as marking the end of the old covenant and the arrival of the kingdom
Jesus Christ sees him as the promised Elijah

primaryrefs.comment: On the basis of Malachi's prophecy (Mal 4:5), it was widely accepted that Elijah must come before the Messiah could appear. This identification would have been reinforced by John dressing like Elijah (see 2Ki 1:8).

children.title: Mary, mother of Jesus Christ
children.comment: Mary, the mother of Jesus Christ, provides Christians with an example of obedience to God and trust in Christ. She shared in the sufferings of her son, and took her place alongside the other disciples.

children.title: She was related to Elizabeth, a descendant of Aaron

primaryrefs.comment: The Greek word translated ``virgin'' means ``young'', ``unmarried'' and implies virginity. Betrothal might take place as early as 12 years old and lasted usually for a year, being as binding as a marriage contract, though without sexual relations.

cschildren.title: The events in Mary's life leading up to the birth of Jesus Christ

children.title: Mary's response of submission and obedience
The Magnificat expresses Mary's wonder and joy

secondaryrefs.comment: Joseph and Mary were poor and they could not afford to offer a lamb (see Lev 12:8).

children.title: She could not dominate Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: At the wedding at Cana.
Many Christians see this as the poignant fulfilment of Simeon's prophecy in Lk 2:35.

children.title: Melchizedek
children.comment: ``King of Righteousness'': king and priest of Salem, who blessed Abraham. David assumed Melchizedek's role as king and priest of Jersualem for himself and his descendants. Jesus Christ succeeded to this role and became a high priest in the order of Melchizedek.

cschildren.title: Melchizedek was both king and priest

children.title: As a king, Melchizedek entertained Abraham
As a priest, Melchizedek blessed Abraham
Abraham acknowledged Melchizedek as a priest of the LORD

primaryrefs.comment: Melchizedek here points ahead to Jesus Christ, who is also priest and king.

children.title: David appropriates Melchizedek's office and authority for himself and his descendants

primaryrefs.comment: The word ``order'' here means ``in succession to'', meaning that Christ assumes the status and function of Melchizedek.

children.title: The Davidic Messiah (Christ) inherits the office of Melchizedek

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ was at that time being acclaimed as the ``Son of David'' and by implication here claims to be the Messiah.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ as high priest after the order of Melchizedek

primaryrefs.comment: Only the high priest could sacrifice for the sins of the nation in the inner sanctuary behind the curtain.

children.title: The characteristics of the order of Melchizedek

primaryrefs.comment: Melchizedek's order of priesthood was one of kingship, peace and righteousness; it did not depend on genealogical descent (unlike the Levitical priesthood); it is eternal, without known beginning or end.

children.title: The uniqueness of Jesus Christ's high priesthood in the order of Melchizedek

primaryrefs.comment: Melchizedek was superior to Abraham and therefore to the Levitical priesthood descended from Abraham
The priesthood is secured by God's oath.

children.title: Jesus Christ's high priesthood makes the Levitical priesthood obsolete
Moses
children.comment: One of the most important figures in the OT. Moses was called by God to lead Israel out of captivity in Egypt through the Sinai wilderness to the brink of the promised land. He was the mediator of the old covenant, and in several major respects anticipates the person of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Moses, life of
children.comment: The life of Moses sets the scene for the great events of the exodus from Egypt, and the showing forth of the power of the LORD, culminating in the giving of the covenant at Sinai and the preparations for entry into the promised land.

children.title: The meaning of the name Moses
God reveals himself to Moses at the burning bush
He is called to deliver his people

seealsos.comment: Moses is given Aaron as spokesman.

children.title: Moses and Aaron speak to Pharaoh
Pharaoh's disobedience leads to the plagues
The death of the firstborn in Egypt
Moses leads Israel in the exodus from Egypt
The crossing of the Red Sea
The establishment of the covenant with Moses
Moses is given the Ten Commandments
He smashes the tablets because of the people's idolatry
He puts the new stone tablets in the ark
Moses leads Israel in the wilderness
He asks to see the glory of the LORD
The LORD promises his presence on the journey
Moses on the brink of the promised land
He takes a census before the entry into Canaan
He is vindicated against the grumblers
He is prohibited from entering the promised land
Moses, significance of
children.comment: Moses performed a number of major roles in the history of Israel. Many of these roles later found their perfection in Jesus Christ.

children.title: As the mediator of the law and the covenant
He was a man of faith
He understood that the law meant life
He was passionate in his defence of the Lord's holiness
He worked miracles that brought glory to God
He fathers, and is identified with, the Judaic legal system
He inaugurates the ritual slaughter of the Passover lamb
He sprinkles the people with the blood of the covenant
Moses enters the glory of the LORD
Jesus Christ is superior to Moses
Moses, foreshadower of Jesus Christ
children.comment: Moses foreshadows Jesus Christ in his role as a law-giver, as a mediator between God and his people and as a prophet who declared the will of God. In these matters, Jesus Christ brought to perfection the work begun through Moses.

children.title: Parallels between the infancies of Moses and Jesus Christ
Moses' mother hid him to escape the slaughter decreed by Pharaoh
Herod's attempt to slaughter Jesus Christ
Moses, the Israelite exile in Egypt and Midian
Joseph takes Jesus Christ to Egypt for safety

secondaryrefs.comment: Moses, like Jesus Christ, had no settled home in his own country.

children.title: Supernatural signs confirmed the callings both of Moses and Jesus Christ
Parallels between Moses and Jesus Christ
As those who reveal the glory of God
Moses as servant; Jesus Christ as Son
Moses, life of
children.comment: The life of Moses sets the scene for the great events of the exodus from Egypt, and the showing forth of the power of the LORD, culminating in the giving of the covenant at Sinai and the preparations for entry into the promised land.

children.title: The meaning of the name Moses
God reveals himself to Moses at the burning bush
He is called to deliver his people

seealsos.comment: Moses is given Aaron as spokesman.

children.title: Moses and Aaron speak to Pharaoh
Pharaoh's disobedience leads to the plagues
The death of the firstborn in Egypt
Moses leads Israel in the exodus from Egypt
The crossing of the Red Sea
The establishment of the covenant with Moses
Moses is given the Ten Commandments
He smashes the tablets because of the people's idolatry
He puts the new stone tablets in the ark
Moses leads Israel in the wilderness
He asks to see the glory of the LORD
The LORD promises his presence on the journey
Moses on the brink of the promised land
He takes a census before the entry into Canaan
He is vindicated against the grumblers
He is prohibited from entering the promised land
Moses, significance of
children.comment: Moses performed a number of major roles in the history of Israel. Many of these roles later found their perfection in Jesus Christ.

children.title: As the mediator of the law and the covenant
He was a man of faith
He understood that the law meant life
He was passionate in his defence of the Lord's holiness
He worked miracles that brought glory to God
He fathers, and is identified with, the Judaic legal system
He inaugurates the ritual slaughter of the Passover lamb
He sprinkles the people with the blood of the covenant
Moses enters the glory of the LORD
Jesus Christ is superior to Moses
Moses, foreshadower of Jesus Christ
children.comment: Moses foreshadows Jesus Christ in his role as a law-giver, as a mediator between God and his people and as a prophet who declared the will of God. In these matters, Jesus Christ brought to perfection the work begun through Moses.

children.title: Parallels between the infancies of Moses and Jesus Christ
Moses' mother hid him to escape the slaughter decreed by Pharaoh
Herod's attempt to slaughter Jesus Christ
Moses, the Israelite exile in Egypt and Midian
Joseph takes Jesus Christ to Egypt for safety

secondaryrefs.comment: Moses, like Jesus Christ, had no settled home in his own country.

children.title: Supernatural signs confirmed the callings both of Moses and Jesus Christ
Parallels between Moses and Jesus Christ
As those who reveal the glory of God
Moses as servant; Jesus Christ as Son
Noah
children.comment: A figure of major importance in the early chapters of Genesis, with whom God established a covenant, the sign of which was the rainbow. The life of Noah (whose name means ``rest'' or ``comfort'') demonstrates God's ability to save the righteous and destroy the ungodly.

children.title: Noah illustrates God's restoring grace after judgment
Noah built the ark at God's command
Noah saved his family and animals from the flood
God established a covenant with Noah, the sign of which is the rainbow
Noah lived to a great age
Noah was a man of the soil
Noah was subject to human frailty

primaryrefs.comment: Nakedness was seen as shameful by OT writers.

children.title: Noah blessed and cursed his sons in a prophetic way

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ was a direct descendant of Noah
The last days are likened to the time of Noah

children.title: Paul
children.comment: The ``apostle to the Gentiles''. Converted from Judaism by an encounter with the risen Christ, Paul planted and corresponded with churches through much of the Mediterranean. In his letters, Paul stresses the universality of the gospel, which knows no distinction between Jew and Gentile, and the effects of Christian faith upon life and conduct.

children.title: Paul, life of
children.comment: Paul, previously known as Saul, had been a zealous persecutor of the church, but an encounter with the risen Christ (c. A.D. 35) led to his becoming the apostle to the Gentiles, with a mission to proclaim the gospel throughout the Gentile world. He was probably martyred during the persecutions of Nero, possibly in A.D. 67.

children.title: His place of birth and education
His conversion on the road to Damascus and his apostolic calling

primaryrefs.comment: Acts makes no mention of this trip, but it seems that Paul went to Arabia immediately after he met Ananias and then subsequently returned to preach in Damascus.

children.title: His return to his home town of Tarsus

seealsos.comment: Tarsus was in Cilicia.

children.title: Paul's first missionary journey and his partnership with Barnabas (c. A.D. 46-48)
Paul and the Council of Jerusalem (c. A.D. 49)
children.precomment: The similarities between Paul and Luke here suggests that both writers are referring to the same events in these passages. Some, however, prefer to equate the meeting recorded in Gal 2:1-10 with the journey to Jerusalem mentioned in Ac 11:30:

children.title: His disagreement with Barnabas and his new partnership with Silas

secondaryrefs.comment: It was from Corinth that Paul wrote to the Thessalonians.

children.title: His general purpose in making his journey

secondaryrefs.comment: Most scholars believe that Paul wrote 1Corinthians from Ephesus, and that he also visited Corinth during this period. This visit, however, proved to be such a painful experience for him that he abandoned plans for a third visit, and instead wrote the Corinthians a ``tearful'' letter, calling them to repent of their sinful behaviour.

Paul had hoped that Titus would bring him news from Corinth. They finally met in Macedonia, and Titus brought good news about the Corinthians' change of heart. Paul then wrote 2Corinthians before visiting Corinth for a third time.

children.title: His return to Jerusalem with the collection

secondaryrefs.comment: Paul wrote Romans at this point in his travels. There is a considerable degree of uncertainty as to precisely when Galatians, Ephesians, Philippians, Colossians and Philemon were written.

children.title: The latter part of Paul's life
children.precomment: These verses from the Pastoral Epistles may indicate that Paul was ultimately released and undertook further journeys in the Eastern Mediterranean before his death:

children.title: Paul, apostle to Gentiles
children.comment: Paul saw his encounter with the risen Christ as a call to apostleship, with a special mission to proclaim the gospel to the Gentile world. Paul's complete dedication to Jesus Christ made his own personal weaknesses a vehicle for the power of God.

children.title: Paul's calling as an apostle: origins and implications
His calling began with his encounter with the risen Christ
His calling involved his being sent to the unevangelised Gentile world
His calling put him under an obligation to preach the gospel
Paul's commitment to his apostolic calling
He supported himself in order to present the gospel free of charge
He put the gospel before everything else
He experienced God's power at work through him
He had a confident attitude to death
Paul and the example of Jesus Christ
His appeal to Jesus Christ as an example to the churches

primaryrefs.comment: Paul here uses the example of Jesus Christ in order to encourage the Corinthians in their giving.

children.title: His own exemplary imitation of Jesus Christ
His sharing of Jesus Christ's sufferings

primaryrefs.comment: Paul is not suggesting here that there is any deficiency in Jesus Christ's atoning sacrifice. Rather, there are some aspects of suffering which Christ could not experience because they arose only as a result of people preaching the message of the cross and suffering because of it.

children.title: His integrity in dealing with the churches
His dependence on the prayers of the churches

secondaryrefs.comment: Paul portrays God as a victorious Roman general, with himself as a captive, bringing up the rear of the triumphal procession.

children.title: As Jesus Christ's slave
children.precomment: The word translated ``servant'' in these verses commonly meant ``slave'':

children.title: Paul's successors were to safeguard the truth of the gospel after his death
Paul, teaching of
children.comment: Paul's understanding of the Christian life was dominated by the importance of Jesus Christ's death and resurrection, by means of which he saw God as having acted decisively to redeem the world. Paul emphasised that Jews and Gentiles alike are justified by faith, and share together in the glorious new era of the Holy Spirit, which is to be consummated at Christ's return.

children.title: The redeeming work of Jesus Christ
God's work of redemption in Jesus Christ's death and resurrection
Jesus Christ as substitute, exchanges places with the sinner
Jesus Christ reverses the effects of Adam's sin
The death and resurrection of Jesus Christ mark the beginning of God's new order
New life comes through the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ's death and resurrection are the basis for a new moral life
Those who participate in God's new order are ``in Christ''

seealsos.comment: Paul extends the scope of the phrase ``in Christ'' to include believers, their activity, and the salvation they have received.

children.title: Both Jews and Gentiles are justified by faith
Paul stresses that salvation is by grace through faith alone
Jewish works of the law have no role in salvation
Both Jews and Gentiles are united in the one body of Christ
His indwelling is an integral part of Christian experience

seealsos.comment: Paul's questions suggest that he identifies receiving the Spirit with becoming a Christian.

children.title: He equips the church with gifts
He enables believers to relate to God as Father
He guides believers into a right understanding of the law
He overcomes believers' sinful human nature
He is the guarantee of eternal life
Paul lived in the hope of the forthcoming personal return of the risen Christ
Believers are to be raised with Christ upon his return
The whole created order will be renewed at the return of Jesus Christ

children.comment: Paul, previously known as Saul, had been a zealous persecutor of the church, but an encounter with the risen Christ (c. A.D. 35) led to his becoming the apostle to the Gentiles, with a mission to proclaim the gospel throughout the Gentile world. Peter
children.comment: The foremost of the disciples of Jesus Christ during his lifetime and of the apostles after the resurrection.

children.title: Peter, the disciple
children.comment: The son of Jonas or John, he was called Simon until Jesus Christ gave him the name Peter meaning ``rock''.

secondaryrefs.comment: He originally came from Bethsaida.

children.title: He was a fisherman by trade
He was called by Jesus Christ
He witnessed Jesus Christ perform many miracles
He was chosen to be with Jesus Christ on certain occasions

secondaryrefs.comment: at the transfiguration of Jesus Christ
in the Garden of Gethsemane

children.title: He sometimes acted as spokesman for the other disciples
children.precomment: He asked Jesus Christ to teach them:

secondaryrefs.comment: He asked Jesus Christ to prolong the transfiguration experience

children.title: His impetuous nature interacted with his devotion to Jesus Christ

secondaryrefs.comment: He wanted to walk to Jesus Christ on the water
He tried to prevent Jesus Christ from going to his death
He vowed that he was willing to die for Jesus Christ

children.title: He was the subject of both special commendation and rebuke

secondaryrefs.comment: He was commended for his confession of faith in Jesus Christ
He was rebuked for his opposition to Jesus Christ's prediction of his suffering
He was warned that he would disown Jesus Christ
He was rebuked for falling asleep in the Garden of Gethsemane

children.title: Peter's denial of Jesus Christ and his reinstatement
He denied that he knew Jesus Christ
The risen Christ appeared to him on his own
He was reinstated by Jesus Christ in front of other disciples
Peter, the apostle
children.comment: As a result of the coming of the Holy Spirit, Peter was transformed into a dynamic apostle and witness to Jesus Christ.

children.title: Peter as an apostle to the Jews
He was the first to baptise Gentiles who had not been circumcised
He defended this action against critics
He later wavered in his attitude to the Gentiles
The miraculous power of the Holy Spirit at work in Peter

secondaryrefs.comment: Peter himself experienced a miracle when imprisoned by Herod Agrippa.
He visited Corinth
He took his wife with him
He visited northern Asia Minor
One interpretation of this verse is that Peter was writing from Rome and was using the name ``Babylon'' symbolically to refer to Rome.

children.title: Peter, preacher and teacher
children.comment: Peter preached mainly to the Jews. He taught both through his preaching and his letters.

children.title: Peter quoted from the OT in his teaching
children.precomment: Referring to the death of Judas:

children.title: About the life and miracles of Jesus Christ
About Jesus Christ's suffering and death
About the resurrection of Jesus Christ
About the ascension and exaltation of Jesus Christ
About the second coming of Jesus Christ
Peter taught about salvation through repentance and faith in Jesus Christ
Peter taught that God cared for all people
Peter wrote his first letter to encourage Christians

seealsos.comment: He exhorted them to live holy lives
They must obey authority
God will vindicate and save his people.

children.title: Peter wrote his second letter to strengthen Christians who were at risk from false teaching

seealsos.comment: He reminded them of the truth of the gospel
He warned them of the judgment awaiting false teachers
They must keep alive their hope in the coming day of the Lord.

children.title: Ruth
children.comment: A young Moabite widow, who, because of her selfless devotion to her mother-in-law Naomi, and to Naomi's God, gained a husband and a child, a place in Jewish history and became the great-grandmother of David and an ancestor of Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: Ruth faces the problems of widowhood

children.title: Boaz allows Ruth to glean in his fields
Ruth asks Boaz to be her ``kinsman-redeemer''

primaryrefs.comment: The kinsman-redeemer was the closest male relative who had responsibility to marry a widow within the family and thereby protect the interests of needy members of the extended family.

children.title: Boaz negotiates with a nearer relative of Ruth's
She has a son who is presented to Naomi

cschildren.title: Ruth is included in the genealogy of Jesus Christ

children.title: Solomon
children.comment: The son of David and Bathsheba, who succeeded David as king of Israel. Noted for his great wisdom, Solomon was responsible for the building of the temple of the LORD. In his latter years, influenced by his many foreign wives, he turned to idolatry.

children.title: Solomon, life of
children.comment: Solomon succeeded his father David as king and secured Israel's stability through treaties with foreign powers.

seealsos.comment: Solomon's Pools

children.title: Solomon, character of
children.comment: Solomon was a man of outstanding gifts and abilities. Initially he was approved by God, but the latter years of his reign were marred by idolatry and apostasy.

children.title: Solomon, life of
children.comment: Solomon succeeded his father David as king and secured Israel's stability through treaties with foreign powers.

seealsos.comment: Solomon's Pools

children.title: Solomon, character of
children.comment: Solomon was a man of outstanding gifts and abilities. Initially he was approved by God, but the latter years of his reign were marred by idolatry and apostasy.
